entry.title: Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting
entry.content:
Motivation

 In SAP Cloud ERP 2508, SAP delivered a new review booklet (template) in Margin Analysis for Company Profitability reporting, showing a 3-level Contribution Margin for a Company Code.

In this article I will   explain the purpose of the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app, how the data for the margin levels is selected, and how you can use the template out of the box.

What Can the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) App Do For You?

The booklet provides Management Accounting insights, which are not yet available on a structured and aggregated level.

It allows a multi-dimensional analysis of contribution margins on 3 levels using Margin Analysis relevant attributes.

 The booklet technology offers highly adaptable financial reporting based on actual postings (ACODCA). This ensures that users have access to precise and detailed information, enhancing decision-making processes.

With advanced formatting options, users can customize reports to suit their needs. The technology also supports downloading and collaboration features, making it easier for teams to work together seamlessly.

As technology advances, so does the booklet. It incorporates AI features, ensuring that users benefit from the latest innovations in financial reporting.

The booklet has standard extensibility functionality to enable adoptability via key user apps.

Contribution Margin Measure Structure And The Reason It Is Called A Template

SAP uses the Functional Areas from Best Practice Content, so the selection needs to be adjusted by customers.

That is why it is called a Template.

If you use the SAP delivered Function Areas (YB18 to YB50) in your cost objects, you can use the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app out of the box.

If not, you need to adjust the selection in the CDS Analytical Query using Key User tools.

I will explain this in another blog.

Key Capabilities

The new review booklet is delivered with SAP Cloud ERP 2508.

It is based on SAP Best Practices Contribution Margin Financial Statement Version (FSV) YPS2 and its semantic tags.

It shows 3 levels of Contribution Margin:
I           Revenues / Related variable costs
II          / Related fixed costs, warranties and variances
III         / Company periodic costs

The booklet is cross-industry, so it can read different account assignments:

  • Market Segments (EO) for Sales Order etc.
  • Projects (PR), with all attributes
  • Service Contracts/Orders (SC, SV), with all attributes
  • Cost Centers (KS, KL) and Orders (OR) for non-allocated costs

With Universal Journal integration we can read costs directly from those cost objects including the attributed Margin Analysis dimensions. There is no need to settle or allocate costs to Market Segments.

Figure 1: Year-to-date comparison of 3-level contribution margin for a company code

 The hierarchical structure of the measures is hard coded in the underlying CDS Analytical Query.

Each measure has semantic tags assigned from FSV YPS2, so GL Account assignments can be adjusted in configuration. You can use your own FSV, but you must use the same semantic tags.

Fixed/variable costs are read from the ACDOCA amount fields.

 you also need to select additional ACDOCA dimensions for the following measures to get correct amounts:

  • Functional Area (to distinguish between COGS and periodic costs)
  • Billable Control (remove warranty costs)
  • Subledger Line Item Type (to distinguish production variances)

Figure 2: Hierarchical measure structure for the 3-level contribution margin

 Data Selection In Detail

The system reads actual revenue and cost in Company Code currency from ACDOCA using the cube I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct with Semantic Tags

 You can access all Margin Analysis data from a set of Cost Objects. Select the Account Assignment Type as follows:

  • EO (Market Segment)
  • PR (Project)
  • SV (Service Order Item)
  • SC (Service Contract)
  • OR (Order)
  • KS (Cost Center)
  • VB (Sales Document Item)
  • KL (Cost Center and Activity)

 You need to distinguish the measures between Read (RKF) and Calculated (Calc) figures.

Calculated figures are based on Read Key Figures and just have a calculation formula without selection criteria.

The Read Key Figures always use a Semantic Tag in the selection.

Please refer to the full list, to get an overview.

Figure 3: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

The reason why additional selection on some figures is required is because SAP uses the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT on several RKFs. PL_RESULT contains all G/L Accounts maintained in the financial statement version.

To ensure we do not count costs on the same account in several key figures, we need to restrict further.

Periodic Costs

Let‚Äôs have a look at the periodic costs first. We want to distinguish periodic costs into the following:

  • Marketing
  • Sales
  • Administration
  • Research & Development

 There are 4 different measures using the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT.

We added the delivered Best Practices FSV YPS2 some more Primary Cost G/L Accounts with SAP Cloud ERP 2508 under a new node called Common Operational Cost Gls (Node ID 74). Please check if you need additional G/L Accounts and add them. If you were a customer before SAP Cloud ERP 2508, you will need to add this node and all G/L Accounts you want to see costs under PL_RESULT.

 The PL_RESULT tag is used here (all costs) to ensure we also see costs in the report that are not being allocated to Margin Analysis using Universal Allocation or Settlement. Primary costs remain on Cost Centers or WBS Element. We could restrict via a Semantic Tag to the corresponding allocation or settlement G/L accounts, if settlement and allocation were done from all object using the secondary G/L Accounts, but this is rarely the case.

 To ensure we have different costs summed on the 4 measures, we use the Functional Areas from Best Practices:

  • YB35: Marketing
  • YB30: Sales
  • YB40: Administration
  • YB50: Research & Development

The Functional Area is always filled in ACDOCA and derived from the Cost Object (Cost Center, WBS Element) on which the periodic costs are posted.

Of course, we continue to display periodic costs allocated or settled to Market Segments. Users can then also drill down into the used dimensions like Product or Customer Group. The system credits allocated costs to the cost center without the Market Segment dimension. This ensures that costs do not appear twice in the total.

 

Figure 4: Example for allocated and non-allocated periodic costs by G/L account in the review booklet

 

Price Differences (Or Production Variances)

A similar case is Price Difference or Production Variance, which can occur on Production Orders and are posted to Market Segment dimensions of a Production Order, once it is completed.

We want to distinguish variance into the following:

  • Input Price
  • Input Quantity
  • Resource Usage
  • Lot Size
  • Output Price
  • Input Remaining

So, we have different Read Key Figures all with Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since different variance can occur on the same G/L Account.

Therefore, we use the Sub-ledger Line Item Type to further restrict the different amounts.

It is filled by production variance calculation in ACDOCA when posted to Market Segments.

Warranty Costs

We also want to show warranty costs as a measure using Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since all kinds of G/L Account can carry warranty cost.

For all warranty costs, the Billable Control (or Accounting Indicator ACDOCA-BEMOT) is filled to configurable values like ‚ÄúNon-Billable Demand‚Äù or ‚ÄúGoodwill‚Äù. This allows us to read with Billable Control not initial.

All Other Costs Of Good Sold

For all other COGS measures in our structure, we make use of the fix and variable separation in ACDOCA and have different sematic tags.

In addition, we use the Best Practice Functional Areas

  • YB18: Cost of Goods Sold
  • YB25: Consulting/Services

 To ensure we only count product and service-related costs in the Contribution Margin I and II we also restrict to Billable Control/Accounting Indicator is initial to not include warranty costs.

 Revenues And Sales Deductions

For revenue and sales deduction figures, it is enough to read the semantic tags and assigned G/L Accounts without the Functional Area.

Navigation to Line-Item Reporting

To verify the aggregated data, users can navigate to the line-item report for Margin Analysis. They can then filter using the criteria for each measure. Semantic tags are resolved into G/L Account through navigation.

Other filters are kept as defined.

Figure 5: Navigation to Display Line Items ‚Äì Margin Analysis to  measure warranty costs

Figure 6: Filters in Display Line Items ‚Äì Margin Analysis to measure warranty costs

The sum in the line-item report should fit the figure in the booklet, with the following limitations:

  • For Fixed/Variable Cost measures, you can verify only the Fixed Amount and need to calculate the Variable as Total minus Fixed.  This is available only for Group Currency.
  • If the booklet includes additional page filters for fields which are not available as filters in the line-item report (e.g. for fiscal quarter), the sum might not match.

Conclusion And Outlook

You now understand the purpose and logic of the booklet and know when you need to adopt.

We would highly appreciate your feedback on this article.

In future we plan to add additional features to the booklet, e.g.

  • Display of amounts in Group Currency
  • Selection and comparison of several Company Codes
  • Commenting
  • Business Insights powered by AI

entry.title: Best practices for keeping up with the SAP Activate content updates
entry.content:
In this post, I intend to share practices and resources that will help you stay in step with the rapid and regular updates in the SAP Activate road maps that SAP delivers to our customers both on the SAP Activate road map viewer (link) and in the SAP Cloud ALM application. We deliver these updates to keep the implementation guidance in step with the innovations introduced in the product and to give our users the latest, up-to-date guidance and accelerators that help them run their transformation projects better. Most of our road maps are on a bi-weekly update cycle, and in some updates, we deliver minor refinements of the content that users may not even notice, while in other updates, we introduce significant updates to support our users in adopting new capabilities.

For example earlier in this year when SAP released Parallel Line capability to all our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public customers on 3-system landscape, the SAP Activate guidance delivered several new tasks and accelerators to help our users to learn about this new capability, request provisioning of the parallel line tenants and explanation on how to use this functionality for parallel configuration activities and how to use transports in this parallel line. There are also examples for the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, where some of our latest additions were bringing the guidance for use of WalkMe, refinement of the Clean Core Quality Gates, and new content for RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. To name just a few.

Now, how can we best keep up with these ongoing updates? There are two main sources for information, one in each of our tools, where SAP delivers SAP Activate to our users. Let‚Äôs start with the SAP Activate in the road map viewer.

Release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer

For the most frequently updated SAP Activate road maps, like SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, you can find dedicated release notes on the Overview page of the road map in the application. See the screenshot below with the highlighted section where you can access the release notes.

When you open the link, you will download a document with release notes that are updated every time we release a new update. These notes provide an overview of the key updates delivered with the new content release. This document is a great source for staying up to date with the new content delivered in each update. You can review it on a regular basis to stay up to date on all the key updates delivered in the SAP Activate road map.

Detailed content update summary in SAP Cloud ALM

Users of SAP Cloud ALM may have noticed a tile ‚ÄúSAP Content Update Summary‚Äù in the Project Overview app (see the screenshot below). The tile provides detailed information about how many tasks have been updated (blue bubble), how many new tasks were delivered in the content update (light gray bubble), and how many tasks have been deprecated (dark gray bubble).

The user can click on each bubble to go to the detailed task list for each category (see the screenshot below). In this screen, you can open the task details by selecting it, assess whether it is relevant to your project, and accordingly assign it to the user or team. If it is not relevant, mark it as such with the status ‚ÄúNot Relevant.‚Äù

Now, let‚Äôs look at the ‚ÄúUpdated‚Äù tasks. We will access the task list the same way we did in the previous step from the Project Overview screen. Then, in the list, we can pick one task to review the details of the change. You will access the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù details by selecting the ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù at the top right side of the screen and selecting the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù item from the menu (see below).

The history opens to the right of the task. In this section of the screen, you can select the time frame for the history (filter button on the right) or change the sorting how the history is shown (sort button on the left). The sorting will present the history from the latest changes at the top (default) or you can change it to see the oldest changes at the top.

This way, you can see all the detailed changes of the content that have been delivered to your project. Like in the example for new tasks, you can assess if the updated task is relevant for your project and if the assigned owner can carry it out. Use the Status and Comments on the task to keep track of your actions and communication with the task owner.

Note that this capability works for both projects created with single SAP Activate roadmap as well as the projects utilizing combined roadmaps in SAP Cloud ALM. In our example, we used a combined roadmap with content from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3-system landscape, SAP SuccessFactors, the Adoption Plan for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Concur.

I hope that this blog post helped you understand how to best utilize the release notes and detailed content history in SAP Cloud ALM to keep yourself up to date on the release updates and your project task list. Please share your feedback in the comments and let me know if you already use these features and what your experience is.

entry.title: Display item of content page on master page in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Displaying a Text Field/Value from the Content Form on the Master Page in Adobe Forms.
Sometimes it can be tricky to display a field from the content page on the master page in Adobe Forms, because the master page does not contain any XML structure in the Data View (except for elements like the logo and footer). The master page does not have direct access to invoice, billing, or other master data.

Assumption: You have already created both a master form template and a content form template according to your business needs.

In this example, I have created:

  • Content form template: YY1_CINV_BILL_BE

  • Master form template: YY1_INVOICE_MASTER_FORM

Scenario

We need to print the invoice number on the master form template (instead of the content form template) because the requirement is to show the invoice number on every page of the PDF output.


Step 1: Download the templates

Download both the content form template and the master form template. After downloading, extract the XDP files and open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

You will notice that the DataConnection Node does not contain the invoice number, because it is part of the content form data. 

 

Now open the content form in Adobe LiveCycle Designer. Here, you can see that the invoice number is available in the content form ‚Äî but our requirement is to also display it on the master form.

Step 2: Bind the invoice number in the content form
Add a Text Field (name it InvoiceNumber) on the content form and bind it to the correct XML node for the invoice number.

Step 3: Create a hidden subform: 

If you want the invoice number to appear only on the master page and not on the content page, create a hidden subform.

  • Set the subform‚Äôs visibility to hidden.

  • Drag the InvoiceNumber text field into this hidden subform.

If you also want the invoice number on the content form, you can skip creating the hidden subform.

Step 4: Add the text field in the master form

Open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer and add a Text Field (also named InvoiceNumber).

In this example, I have added the field to both mst1 and mst2, since the invoice number must appear on both master pages.

Step 5: Write JavaScript to access content form data
Select the textField of the Master Form Template and then write one Javascript code in order to access the data of content form. The Javscript code is written in the Initialize event of the InvoiceNumber textField.

The path (Form.HeaderSubform.HiddenSubform.InvoiceNumber.rawValue) comes from inspecting the content form structure. We simply reference the rawValue of that node.

Step 6: Upload and test

Once the changes are complete in both the content form and the master form:

  1. Save the forms.

  2. Upload them to the public cloud using the Maintain Form Templates app.

 



Finally, test your invoice PDF using the Manage Invoicing Document app. You will now be able to see the invoice number printed on the left side of every master page.
Please let me know if you have any other solution for this requirement.
Happy Learning !!


Thanks,
Shubham

entry.title: Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) now generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Ed. 2508
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce the general availability of the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release ‚Äî now available for the 3-system landscape environment. This marks a significant milestone in empowering customers and partners to create and manage customer local versions at scale with greater flexibility and control.

The need for accelerating innovation due to rapidly changing products, business models, and services is amplified by M&A, new ventures, and divestitures of assets no longer considered core, and esp. by expansion into new markets ‚Äì SAP Cloud ERP  using the Configuration Localization Tool is an excellent foundation to tackle various complexities, be they in payments, tax management or financial reporting across diverse regulatory environments.

With the 2508 release, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now supports local versions for 60 countries/regions in 34 languages, to manage customers‚Äô business processes and still stay compliant by following country/region-specific regulations around accounting, taxes, payments, statutory reporting, electronic document processing. Refer to country/region-specific help for covered compliance.

For markets beyond these 60 SAP-delivered local versions, customers / partners can now build customer local versions on project basis for up to 160 countries/regions using the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) and manage country/region-specific localization requirements with extensibility offered via Localization as a Self-Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - providing the flexibility needed to address market-specific requirements.

During our Early Adoption Program we saw strong customer interest; 86 customers are live with 78 unique customer local versions built in collaboration with 63 partners who also provide extensibility whenever required.

Pls. find an overview on the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) combined with the Parallel Line (PL) here

‚Ä¶and a story about the successful carve-out of Accelleron from its parent company (ABB), based on a common technology foundation, a global process model for 40 countries/regions, finalizing the separation within two years. Localization as a self-service played a key role to help keep the strict timeline and ability to build out 7 missing local version on project basis.

entry.title: A little glance at S/4 Hana OUTPUT MANAGEMENT and compare its to our old friend NAST
entry.content:
As we already know, NAST output has been used over time, from ECC to S4/HANA, due to its reliability and its customization. Based on NAST, we could generate tons of outputs with different types, from simple PDF form or Adobe form to more complex output like EDI/IDOC or even XML.

However, Output management is introduced in S/4 HANA as S/4 HANA OUTPUT MANAGEMENT, as more ‚Äúcentralized‚Äù approach to output, based on BRF+ (business rule framework). FYI, BRF+ has been on SAP from ECC, which supported users specific customizations, based on the role, but applying this for S/4 HANA output management is new thing. Using S/4 HANA Output Management is a less-coding approach, compares to NAST, when you need to do bunches of customizations, which is prefer for consultants than end users.

For short, you can check out this table from our friend :

S/4HANA Output Management vs. NAST: When to Choose... - SAP Community

 

Technology

BRF+

SAPscript / Smart Forms

Customization Flexibility

Limited by service nodes

Customizable to your heart‚Äôs content

Form Type

Adobe Forms

SAPscript, Smart Forms

Output Types

Print, Email, XML, EDI

Print, Email, Fax, EDI

Multiple Outputs per Document

BRF+ (but expect headaches)

Easier management with condition records

Learning Curve

Steep‚Äîbetter grab some coffee 

Familiar, like catching up with an old friend

Centralized Management

Yes‚Äîstreamlined oversight

Traditional, less streamlined

Future-Proofing

Yes‚Äîleverages the latest technology

No‚Äîlegacy technology means potential obsolescence

Recommended Use Case

Standard scenarios, new systems

Custom-heavy projects, legacy systems

For short, we can understand that, using NAST is like our reliable, multi functional car that can ramp up anything, just look not really good, but Output Management is introduced as sport cars, like a F1 Mercedes AMG W16, that could only drive on an F1 track.

The purpose of this blog is not to deep dive on theoretical questions how better or how worse of each method, but to know how the configuration of output management, is it much easier than a NAST approach?

Let I guide you steps by steps

HOW SETUP OF OUTPUT MANAGEMENT

To check out our Output Management,  lets come to our SPRO -> Cross-Application Components -> Output Control

As we can see, there are bunches of configurations, that are very easy to recognize than our NACE t-code setup. As we know, NACE t-code is follow  based on our condition technique setup, which it takes the combinations of key index and cross-check the condition record, then the medium things and routine things follow up.

Lets look how can activate the Output Management before NAST

Next step, we can go to Define Output Types




As we can see, for each Object Types, Output Management support not only different ranges of Output Type but also the variance of the Output, which is different approach from NAST.  

Let‚Äôs take the Change for example. In NAST, we can retrigger the old output by in case of changes. The same output will be trigger once again when we hit save on the document. But for the Output Management, we could have our own ‚Äúchanges‚Äù output here.

Let‚Äôs check this output type for ‚ÄúCash Sales Changes‚Äù as below



Double click on the Callback Class.

As we can see just one type of Output, we can see the API information or type of forms/mediums that the output can support in this case

Next step, as we remember from our Friend NAST, in order to generate an output , we need to know which medium (EDI, Printer, Email, Tax).. For each type of output, if you remember, we have this screen in NACE:



For Output Management, we follow BRF+ (Business Rule Framework), so we do not follow Condition Technique.

So it means that for each output type, you have different means of Channel (or Medium if you are in NACE/NAST). Each Output type has their own channel, and each output type has their own form templates or their own email templates. We can check at detail at ‚ÄúAssign Form Template‚Äù or ‚ÄùAssign Email Template‚Äù

Enough for the setup, let‚Äôs get to the most important part of our Output Management.

instead of Output procedure or condition technique we have to deal with, Output management with the help of BRF+, use the ‚ÄúBusiness Rules for Output Determination‚Äù

As you can see, since its not follow the Condition Technique, Output Management helps user to setup the rule with friendly UI. However, for me Condition Technique is less complex than, because it is used not only for Output but also for Pricing for Sales, Pricing for Purchasing or Tax Determination (just my 2 cents).

Let‚Äôs get back to our Business rule:

For Output type, we can input the combinations we like (of course base on the table related to the situations, again, more user-friendly, less consultant-friendly (your pick)

For other‚Äôs determination, these can base on the same rule for Receiver, Printer Settings, etc. Just the same as Condition Record, but at more ‚Äúuser-friendly‚Äù

After all the setup, get back to how our Output type working in Transactional situation, in this case is the Purchase Order:

As you can see, when we activate the Output Management, the old screen of NAST is no longer, instead, its now generate new type of screen. In this screen, we input PRINT ‚Äúchannel‚Äù as our medium in this case. Click on line, choose button ‚ÄùDisplay Details‚Äù:

Or we can look over if we use ‚ÄúEMAIL‚Äù channel, you can easily put CC or BCC for email address

CONCLUSIONS

As we can see how easily that users can access to their output and adjust their output with just simple modifications, even add emails for CC or BCC purposes. However, we also see that how frustration Output Management can bring out whenever if we want to have new type of forms, or any new heavy-customized oriented conditions, while NAST can provide us with just few clicks.  So we surely know that S/4 Hana Output Management could be used in the situations that are more centralized, more " basic" and less "complicated", while our NAST could be trustworthy at all the time, but both of them are solutions to different scenarios so don't just stick to only one. Be flexible within the situation.

entry.title: Custom Journal Entry Query by G/L and Cost Center in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, reporting on Journal Entries often requires not only grouping by GL Accounts but also breaking down the information based on Cost Centers. This can be critical for department-level spend control or management reporting where even costs on the same account need to be analyzed separately.

In this blog post, I will show how to create a Custom Analytical Query that splits entries on the same GL account into separate rows based on Cost Center.

Use case

We want to analyze expenses posted to G/L account 61400000 ("Training and Education") across multiple cost centers. Although the same account is used, it is important to distinguish which department owns the expense.

 
Journal EntryG/L AccountAmountCost CenterCost Center Description
10000012361400000500HR001HR Department
10000012461400000300IT002IT Department
10000012561400000700SALES003Sales Department

Prerequisites

Ensure your user has the following roles assigned:

Business RoleBusiness Role ID
Analytics SpecialistSAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
General Ledger AccountantSAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT
 
If you don‚Äôt have the necessary roles, please contact your administrator or refer to the Maintain Business Users app.

Implementation

To implement the custom query, you‚Äôll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

Within the query, you‚Äôll define Restricted Structure Elements to represent specific combinations of G/L Accounts and Cost Centers. This allows you to display postings to the same account in separate rows depending on the cost center dimension. If required, you can further build a –°ustom Report or Fiori tile on top of the query for easier access and integration into business users' daily activities.

1. Open the Custom Analytical Queries app (F1572)

Click "Create"

2. Create a Custom Analytical Query

In the opened window, set the Query Name (for example, CUSTOMREPORT), Data Source (I_JOURNALENTRYITEMCUBE) and select "OK".

To implement the custom report, you‚Äôll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

3. Fill in the parameters in the "General" tab

The General window is used to configure the main properties of a custom analytical query. It provides key settings that define the query's behavior, metadata, and runtime characteristics.

  • Label ‚Äì name for the query that will be displayed in the system (e.g. CUSTOMREPORT)
  • Processing Effort ‚Äì allows prioritization of query performance (e.g. High)
  • Runtime Extensibility ‚Äì a checkbox indicating whether runtime extensibility is enabled for the query.
  • Handling  ‚Äì specifies how zero values in the query results are handled (e.g. None)
  • Hide on Axis ‚Äì determines whether zero-suppressed rows or columns are hidden (e.g. Rows & Columns)

After filling in the fields, navigate to the Field Selection tab.

4. Define the fields in the "Field Selection" tab

The "Field Selection" window is used to define the fields included in the query and specify how they are positioned in the query output (e.g., as rows, columns, or free fields). This setup controls the structure and content of the query results.

Available Fields ‚Äì displays a list of all fields available from the query's data source.

  • Selected Fields ‚Äì shows the fields that have been added to the query.
  • Row ‚Äì fields added to this section will define the row structure of the query results.
  • Column ‚Äì fields added to this section define the column structure of the query results.
  • Free ‚Äì fields in this section are not directly displayed in the query results but are available for filtering or grouping during query execution.

Selected Fields ‚Äì displays the fields that have been added to the query. It includes fields selected from the Available Fields section and organizes them into Row, Column, Measure Structure, or Free, depending on their role in the report layout.

After selecting the fields, navigate to the Display tab.

5. Define the fields in the "Display" tab

The "Display" window is used to configure the layout and behavior of fields in the query output. It allows users to determine which fields appear as rows, columns, or free fields, as well as customize properties such as display options, sorting, and formatting. Fields can be reassigned between Row, Column, and Free using either drag-and-drop or the Axis property in the Properties panel or Up, Down, Add buttons.

To enhance your report logic, additional elements can be added via the Add button:

  • Add Restricted Measure ‚Äì creates a key figure with a predefined filter condition (e.g., only for a specific company code or fiscal year).
  • Add Calculated Measure ‚Äì defines new key figures based on arithmetic or logical operations involving existing ones.
  • Add Converted Measure ‚Äì generates a key figure with unit conversion applied (e.g., currency or quantity unit).
  • Add Counter ‚Äì introduces a counter that increments for each record, which is useful for record numbering or counting occurrences.
  • Add User Input Filter ‚Äì adds a filter field that prompts the user to enter a value during query execution. This allows for dynamic filtering based on user input.
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element ‚Äì enables more advanced layout or logic customization by defining reusable field structures.

In our example, we will use a Characteristic Structure Element to customize the output view of the query. To add it, —Ålick the Add button and select Add Characteristic Structure Element from the dropdown menu.

In the dialog window that opens, select "OK".

In the Characteristic Structure Element dialog, you can define the properties of the structure element that will be added to your report layout:

  • Label ‚Äì specifies the display name of the structure element, which will appear as a column header in the query result (e.g., 1.1. HR Expenses).
  • Name ‚Äì provides a unique technical identifier for the structure element used internally within the query (e.g., HRExpenses).
  • Structure Element ‚Äì determines the type of structure element to create:
    • Restricted Structure Element ‚Äì aggregates data based on predefined filter criteria (e.g., specific G/L account and cost center).
    • Calculated Structure Element ‚Äì creates a key figure based on calculations involving other structure elements (e.g., differences, percentages).

In our example, we select Restricted Structure Element to isolate and display values that match specific filtering conditions.

Once the settings are defined, click OK to proceed.

6. Define Characteristic Structure Elements

Once the Characteristic Structure Element has been added, it appears in the Row section of the Display tab. On the right-hand side of the screen, the Properties allows further customization:

  • Label ‚Äì choose between a static label (manually defined) or a dynamic label (generated based on logic or field values). In our example, the element is Static.
  • Name ‚Äì the technical identifier for internal use in query logic.
  • Display ‚Äì enables or disables visibility of the element in the report output.
  • Decimals ‚Äì defines the number of decimal places shown in the report output.
  • Scaling ‚Äì allows automatic scaling of numerical values (e.g., thousands, millions).
  • Reverse Sign ‚Äì reverses the sign of key figure values, often used to display credits as negatives.

Hierarchy ‚Äì controls how the element behaves in a hierarchical display:

  • Collapsed ‚Äì when enabled, the hierarchy node is shown collapsed by default, hiding its children until expanded by the user.
  • Enable Hierarchy ‚Äì activates the hierarchy mode for the element, allowing parent-child relationships to be displayed. 
  • Parent ‚Äì specifies the parent node for the current element when hierarchy mode is active.

Collision Handling ‚Äì defines how formatting and calculation settings are applied when different definitions conflict:

  • Formula ‚Äì determines whether the formula from the current element or from the collision source takes precedence.
  • Decimal ‚Äì specifies which decimal setting  should be applied in case of conflict.
  • Scaling ‚Äì specifies which scaling factor should be applied in case of conflict.

In the Fixed Values section at the bottom, you can define restrictions that determine which data is included in the structure element. In this case, a fixed filter is applied on the Account Assignment field using the Include option. This filter is the core of the Restricted Structure Element, as it ensures that only relevant records (e.g., for a specific G/L account and cost center) are used in calculations.

To refine the restriction criteria, click Add Restriction. You can specify multiple conditions based on various dimensions, such as G/L Account, Cost Center, or Functional Area.

In the Dimensions window, select the G/L Account field.


On the Include tab, select the "=" operator and define the account 61400000.

Similarly, define the restriction for cost center HR001.
To remove an unnecessary restriction (for example,  Account Assignment), select the Remove Restriction function.

Similarly, define the Characteristic Structure Element for 1.2. IT Expenses (account 61400000, cost center IT002) and 1.3. Sales Expenses (account 61400000, cost center SALES003).

To add a node, select Add Characteristic Structure Element and define the Label, Name, and Structure Element (Calculated Structure Element).
To define a summation formula for the previously created expense rows, go to the Expression section and click Edit.
Define the formula using mathematical operators and the list of available measures.
To define the created node as hierarchical, go to the previously created expense rows, check Enable Hierarchy in the Hierarchy section, and specify the parent node.

7. Define the fields in the "Filters" tab

The Filters tab is used to define the selection criteria that control which data is displayed in the report or structure. Filters help limit the dataset to the relevant scope by specifying fixed values, allowing user input during execution, or leaving the field unrestricted.

For the selected fields, you can define the following filter settings:

  • No filters ‚Äì allows all values; no restriction applied.
  • Fixed Values ‚Äì choosing fixed values defines a permanent filter value. End users cannot reconfigure this value. You can specify:
    • Include ‚Äì values that must be included in the dataset.
    • Exclude ‚Äì values that must be excluded from the dataset
  • User Input Values ‚Äì upon query execution, this option enables end users to choose a value that filters the result set. The following settings are possible for User Input Values:
    • Selection Type ‚Äì this option enables you to enter a single value, a value range, or a hierarchy node option to define the filter condition. The hierarchy node option appears only if a field supports a hierarchy. And the hierarchy node option displays the hierarchy tree in the User Input Filter screen.
    • Multiple Selection (checkbox) ‚Äì this option enables the end user to choose multiple values as input during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) ‚Äì this option ensures that the end user must make an entry.
    • Variable Sequence ‚Äì this option enables you to maintain the order of the parameter. During execution, the fields with variable sequence defined will take the first priority to the fields that have no value maintained for the same.
    • Default Value ‚Äì the value that you enter in this field appears in the User Input Value field and is displayed to the end user.
  • Derivation Functions ‚Äì this option enables automatically derive the filter value based on predefined logic or relationships with other fields. 
    • Lookup Entity ‚Äì defines the source for value help assistance for the field. This could be a CDS view, master data table, or other value provider.
    • Hide (checkbox) ‚Äì when selected, the field will not be displayed to the end user in the filter selection screen, but any fixed value or derivation logic applied to it will still be active during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) ‚Äì ensures that the filter must be provided before the query can be executed.

After defining all parameters (for example, Company Code, Ledger, Fiscal Year, Fiscal Period), you can save the draft of your Custom Analytical Query by selecting the Save Draft option. After saving, you can preview the custom query by selecting the Preview option.

In the window that opens, you will see a preview of your query.

After reviewing the query, you can return to the previous window and publish the Custom Analytical Query by clicking the Publish button.

After the query is successfully published, its status will change to Published.

Summary
In this blog post, we created a custom journal entry query by G/L account and cost center in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

We walked through the process of designing the query, configuring parameters and input options, previewing the results, and publishing it for use.

Once published, this query can serve as a powerful reporting tool, or act as a data source for custom applications, enabling more targeted financial insights.

Let me know if you‚Äôve implemented similar custom analytical queries!

entry.title: Material Documents Overview app key features - S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Material Documents Overview (F1077) brings this same functionality than the Display Material Document list (MB51), but with a more intuitive interface, better navigation, and embedded analytics.

With this app, you can view material documents related to goods movements. It also allows you to display the associated purchase orders and sales orders for each document.

  • Improved performance ‚Äì faster response times;
  • Better usability ‚Äì cleaner and more intuitive interface;
  • Enhanced navigation and filtering capabilities;
  • Add attachments to the material document;
  • Determine forms of output for a material document, such as print output or electronic data interchange (EDI);
    • When you perform a stock movement , such as a transfer or a goods receipt ‚Äî the system generates a material document. Depending on the system configuration (using Output Management), this document can trigger different types of outputs, such as:
  • Print output: for example, a physical form to be used in the warehouse
  • EDI: an electronic confirmation sent directly to an external partner
  • Email or PDF: automatic notifications or attachments sent to relevant users or departments.
    • In the Items section, we can select the row of material document item to view all the output management information ‚Äì In this section you can Preview Goods Receipt Slip for example, with the right setup in the Output Parameter Determination app. Here we can see that there is an EDI configured in channel to this kind of document.
    • MMIM_MATDOC_GDSMVMT_ESO: For EDI there are no printer settings. An EDI-message has no form templates as attachment.

  • Share the material document using chat in Microsoft Teams or send Email;
  • Reverse or partially reverse a selected material document;
    • It's not possible to split a document within the app, so a partial reversal can only be applied to material documents that were posted with two or more separate line items. So let‚Äôs jump to the example to show  how  partial reverse works ‚Äì first I post a good receipt with two line items and than, inside of the Material Documents Overview app, it's possible to reverse just one line.

  • Generate report from material documents with the summarize option;
    • The information displayed is editable, which means the content may not be fully trustable as an official document
    • The tool only allows us to copy all the data, but it doesn‚Äôt, for example, generate a PDF

  • Display the associated purchase orders and sales orders with the material documents;
  • Show the assigned valuation type for the split valuated material - So if a material has multiple valuation types, you can either filter by one or display all the assigned types

     

Useful links: 

  • https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1077')/S35
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/7cc07e548af58e4ce10000000a4450e5.html?version=2508.500
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/924584d1ecc849efb0762f1ff319ba00.html?state=DRAFT&q=MMIM_MATDOC_GDSMVMT_ESOA
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/output-management-in-s-4hana/ba-p/13762541

entry.title: Stock ‚Äì Multiple Materials key features - S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Display Warehouse Stock (MB52) is now replaced by Stock ‚Äì Multiple Materials (F1595), an app that provides the same visibility ‚Äî but in a more interactive and responsive way. It supports personalization, grouping, exporting, and even better performance with large data volumes. Users can view stock by material, location, special stock, and unit of measure ‚Äî all with real-time integration.

  • Advanced Search Capabilities: several filter options for searching large amounts of data specifically for the required materials;
  • Display a stock overview of one or multiple materials;
  • Display the current value of the stock (using the current material price) or the value of the stock (based on the historical value);
    • Sometimes we work with materials that have variable prices, such as commodities. In these cases, the current price might not reflect the most relevant valuation. Instead, what‚Äôs often more useful is to analyze the historical valuation of the material over time.
  • Display additional storage location information, for example, storage bin (like a shelf, pallet location).
  • Display the carbon footprint of the materials in the plant (with the activation of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Integration into Core Processes);
  • Display the stock with different reporting dates; 
    • Possible to filter by a past date and visualize the stock.
  • Export the result list to a spreadsheet.
  • Send a link to the material document details by e-mail;
  • Share the material document using chat in Microsoft Teams;
  • Schedule Export of Inventory Analytics -
    • With this app, it's possible to schedule a background job to export material stock from the Stock ‚Äì Multiple Materials and posting data for a defined period. This is very useful for inventory control, and it allows to generate the report independently, which makes things much easier. 
    • It's possible to schedule a job in a period of time too.

  • If you access the option inside the Stock ‚Äì Multiple Materials, you have a very limited vision, so it's recommended to access the app Schedule Export of Inventory Analytics.

entry.title: Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer (5HP) in SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
This blog post takes an in-depth look at the advanced intercompany stock transfer - scope item 5HP (as opposed to the Classic Inter-Company Transfer - scope item 1P9 ). This blog offers a comprehensive setup guide, testing procedures, and more implementation details. You can transfer inventory between different legal entities within a corporate group. Within the group, if plants belong to different companies (i.e., have different company codes), inventory can be moved from one plant to another.  If you‚Äôre interested in this business process‚Äîor have questions‚Äîfeel free to leave a comment and discuss!

The features covered in this article are based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508, please refer to the latest information for changes in subsequent versions.

Index

Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer process overview

Business Process Configuration

Business Partner Master Data Configuration

Product Master Data Configuration

Issues worth discussion

 

Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer process overview

Much of the configuration and master data builds on Intercompany Stock Transfer (1P9) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ; This post will focus on highlighting only the new additions. It is suggested to get the 1P9 process running end-to-end first. Building on that foundation will make implementing 5HP much easier since these two scope items can co-exist while Intercompany Sale is another story I will address it later.  Advanced intercompany stock transfer process can be triggered by using a specific purchase order type (e.g. NBIC) that has been enabled for advanced intercompany stock transfer process.

The following process overview helps us understand it better while you have to replace company code 1010 with company code 1320, company code 1710 with company code 1310, plant 1010 with plant 1320, plant 1710 with 1311 in this blog.

Create Intercompany Stock Transfer Order

APP: Create Purchase Order - Advanced (ME21N)

A stock transport order is created for the receiving plant 1320 (Belong to company code 1320) in the item level.  Business Partner PL1311BP in the header represents supplying Plant 1311 (Belong to Company code 1310). The system then recognizes that you are creating a stock transport order when the supplier entered matches a plant in another company code. Then, in the background, the shipping information is determined based on master data and configuration settings.

What‚Äôs different from 1P9 are the order type NBIC and Confirmation Control Key 0004. Please remember to enter storage location or the following inbound delivery creation will encounter issues.

After clicking Save, purchase order 4500000634 created.

You will find this purchase order in APP: Monitor Value Chain after clicking Go

Business Process Tab shows the IC Sales Order has been created automatically.

You can also see the graphical display of the process flow

Create Replenishment Delivery for Stock Transfer Order

App My Purchase Orders - Due for Delivery (VL10B)

The replenishment delivery is created for the appropriate shipping point using the My Purchase Orders Due for Deliveryapp, where the stock transport order number can act as a selection criteria.

Open the app, enter a shipping point, and a due date (optional). The system selects stock transport orders due for delivery. The ship-to party is determined from the configuration: the receiving plant is assigned a business partner master record that represents the ship-to party. You can flag the orders that you want to work on and choose Background. The system then creates replenishment deliveries for these orders in the background.

A green light on indicating outbound delivery successfully created. Go to Monitor Value Chain APP, Outbound Delivery 80000287 has been created automatically.

Process Flow shown as below:

Post Goods Issue from Physical Stock to Stock in Transist of delivering Plant

App: Change Outbound Delivery (VL02N)

After Picking and PGI,  as shown in the following screenshot, Inbound delivery 180000089 have been created automatically. Material document 4900001339 (Mvt681) representing Good Issue for OD into SiT (GIOD) has been created. At this point, the goods have been posted from physical stock of delivering plant to valuated stock in transit of delivering plant which means the ownership remain in delivering plant 1311. Valuated Stock in Transit | SAP Help Portal

At the same time, material document representing ‚ÄòPost GI rom Issuing SiT(GIIV)‚Äô is with a status 'Scheduled' because the Planned Date from outbound delivery header‚Äòs 2025.08.07 00:00 UTC+8 (= 2025.08.06 16:00 UTC). However, you can also input the actual date manually in the Internal Transfer of Control Dates section. If the actual date is in the past, the material document is triggered immediately.  If actual date is in the future, step will be triggered whichever time is earlier between planned date and actual date.

In terms of Stock, after posting goods issue, the quantities of Valuated stock in transit increase by 1 (from 1 to 2). Scheduled for delivery decreased by 1 (from 4 to 3).

APP: Stock Overview (MMBE)

APP: Display Stock in Transit (MB5T)

Post GI from issuing SiT and Post GR to receiving SiT stock

The goods movements are solely controlled via the planned and actual transfer of control dates in the delivery header. Base on these date the Value Chain Monitoring Framework (VCM) will trigger the goods movements. These dates trigger the automatic creation of goods movement using the Valuated Stock in Transit (VSiT) feature. Transfer of Control of Goods | SAP Help Portal

On the date 2025.08.06 18:44 (after 16:00 UTC time), the step Post GI from Issuing SiT has been completed with material document 4900001340 (Mvt685) created. At the same time, step Post Goods Receipt to Receiving SiT (GRRV) was completed automatically too with material document 4900001341 (Mvt107) created. At this moment, these goods are in the control of the receiving company that receives the goods and are part of the valuated stock of the receiving company.

Post Stock Transfer into Receiving Plant Physical Stock

In this step, let‚Äôs confirms that all the materials have been put away in the correct quantities and post good receipts.

APP: Change Inbound Delivery (VL32N), please input Inbound delivery 180000089

VCM shows material document 5000000899 (Mvt109) representing step Post Stock Transfer into Physical Stock (GRID) in receiving plant is completed automatically. And no financial accounting document created.

Inter-Company Supplier invoice will be triggered by this GR automatically.

Create Intercompany Billing Document

Actually the billing document can be posted already when the control of the goods has been transfered from delivering plant to receiving plant in the step Post GI from issuing SiT and Post GR to receiving SiT stock as shown below:

APP: Create Billing document (F0798)

Select the OBD and click create billing document. Choose billing type Intercompany Invoice (IV2) and maintain billing date.

Intercompany Invoice will be created after click SAVE.

Business Process Configuration

Assign Tax Codes for the Transfer of Supplier Invoices

101330 Assign Tax Codes for the Transfer of Supplier Invoices

The purpose of this activity is to assign tax codes to transfer supplier invoice data with a SOAP service. In this activity, you assign tax rates and tax types as sent by your invoicing party to tax codes defined in the system

Enable Value Chain Monitoring for Purchase Orders

SSCUI 105633 Enable Value Chain Monitoring for Purchase Orders

Maintain Intercompany Condition Record

APP: Set Material Prices Sales on condition type PPR0 over Sold to Party CO1320BP

 

Business Partner Master Data Configuration

Please refer to the same section in Intercompany Stock Transfer (1P9) in SAP S/4HANA C... - SAP Community

 

Product Master Data Configuration

Please refer to the same section in Intercompany Stock Transfer (1P9) in SAP S/4HANA C... - SAP Community

 

Issues worth discussion

Issue 1:

Purchase Order pricing and Sales order Pricing are independent and need to be maintained respectively.

More:

entry.title: Master Royalties and Commissions Settlements with SAP Cloud ERP & SAP Subscription Billing
entry.content:
Managing and charging services effectively in a subscription-based business model is crucial for sustained revenue and customer satisfaction. SAP Subscription Billing supports you in handling these aspects by offering intuitive solutions to manage your subscription business efficiently. When integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it empowers organizations to streamline their financial processes. This integration also facilitates efficient and transparent management of complex subsequent settlement processes, such as royalties, internal, and external commissions in an automated manner. Understanding this synergy can transform how your business handles subscription services and the associated settlements, leading to optimized operations and improved financial outcomes.

Exploring Different Settlement Options
1. Intercompany Royalties: 
This settlement option is designed to manage royalties between different entities within the same corporate structure. When one company in a corporate group uses a product or service owned by another entity, intercompany royalties compensate the owning entity. This process ensures precise and compliant revenue distribution within corporate groups, enhancing financial accuracy and facilitating intercompany reconciliation.
2. External Royalties: 
Businesses often need to settle royalties with external entities or licensors who own certain intellectual properties or products that are included in the businesses' own offerings to their customers. These royalties are crucial for fulfilling legal obligations to licensors and securing continuous usage rights for commercially lucrative intellectual properties.
3. Internal Commissions: 
Motivating sales teams through well-structured commission plans can directly impact the success of any business. Internal commissions are calculated based on sales performance and are pivotal in driving sales personnel to achieve their targets. This settlement process ensures that commissions are distributed fairly, based on clear conditions set within the agreement.
4. External Commissions: 
Similar to internal commissions but involving external partners, such as sales agents that help drive sales from outside the company. This commission model must ensure that these external partners are rewarded appropriately for their contributions to driving the company‚Äôs revenue, thereby fostering a healthy and profitable external partnership.

Unlocking Robust Settlement Management Capabilities 
The integration of SAP Subscription Billing with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition enables organizations to unlock advanced tools for managing settlements efficiently. Through the integration scenario Subscription Management with Sales Billing (scope item 57Z), your business can access essential subsequent processes such as:

  • Royalties Settlement for Sales (55I): This scope item facilitates the comprehensive management of intercompany and external royalty settlements. Learn more about Royalties Settlement for Sales.
  • Sales Commissions - External Sales Representative (2TT): Seamlessly handles the settlements of external sales commissions . This scope item supports the management agreements with external sales agents, ensuring accurate and timely settlements aligned with business goals. Explore Sales Commissions for External Representatives.
  • Internal Commissions Settlement for Sales (3TD): Supports internal settlements of sales commissions, enabling businesses to manage employee incentives effectively and promote a performance-driven sales environment. More on Internal Commissions Settlement for Sales.


Condition contract, a central object in Settlement Management, manages all necessary conditions required for settlement, fostering an efficient and transparent process. By leveraging the above mentioned scope items, companies can ensure that their settlement processes are not only comprehensive but are also finely tuned to their specific business requirements. To accommodate variations from the default settlement process, each scope item comes with process variants. See the respective test scripts for details via the links above.

Conclusion 
Integrating SAP Subscription Billing with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition amplifies your operational efficiency. It streamlines the settlement aspect of your business. With robust features and seamless integration, the solution ensures your financial settlement processes are automated, making your operations effortlessly smooth and efficient.

Related Information 
Explore deeper into each specific settlement process:

  • Royalties Settlement 
  • Internal Commissions Settlement 
  • External Commissions Settlement

Co-Author: @shweta_kesarwani.

entry.title: Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution.  

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem‚Äìcustomers, partners, and SAP experts. 

This blog shares highlights on Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

  • Price analysis on service contract items
  • Capturing purchase order number on service contract item level
  • Change capabilities for mass updates of service contracts

Watch my video to get a glimpse of the new features:

 

 

Price analysis on service contract items

With this feature, you can view price determination analysis at the item level of service transactions such as service contracts, service orders, solution orders, and so on. Price determination analysis displays the pricing procedure used for the item. It helps you understand how a condition amount was determined and to figure out, for example, why a specific price element has not been found by pricing. This includes information about which accesses were executed, which were not executed, and why they were not executed, as well as which fields and field values were used for the access.

This feature directly addresses the common challenge of understanding complex price calculations. Pricing experts often face situations where the final price is not what they expect, with certain price conditions not being applied or unknown factors influencing the outcome. This lack of transparency leads to confusion and significant time spent troubleshooting. The new price analysis tool provides clarity by breaking down the price determination process, empowering users to self-diagnose issues efficiently. This reduces the need for support inquiries and ensures that pricing logic is transparent, auditable, and configured correctly to meet business requirements.

Let's take the service contracts for example. Located within the "Manage Service Contracts" app, the price analysis is located at the service contract item level. Within the "Price Details" tab, a new "Analyze" button is now available. Clicking this button opens a detailed, step-by-step log of the entire price determination process for that specific item. This technical view uses clear visual indicators: green for conditions that were successfully met and applied, and red for those that were not. Users can expand the log for a full-screen view and drill down into each step to see the specific price element, the condition evaluated, and the logic behind its success or failure. This granular breakdown provides the necessary evidence to understand precisely how the final price was calculated, making it an indispensable tool for debugging complex pricing.

Watch this demo to have a complete view of the feature.

 

 

Capturing purchase order number on service contract item level

With this feature, you can specify external references for service contract items in the Manage Service Contracts app. It can help you identify all relevant service contract items with the same customer purchase order, accelerating the billing process.  Additionally, the system now can automatically forward the item-level, instead of the header-level, external references to billing document requests and, subsequently, to billing documents.

This feature enhances traceability and simplifies financial processing by creating a clear, direct link between a specific service contract item and a customer's purchase order. By capturing the PO number at the item level, businesses can easily identify and reference the specific customer authorization for each service. This linkage carries through to the final billing document, making invoices much clearer for both the internal billing team and the customer. This improved clarity helps streamline invoice processing, reduces confusion or disputes, and ultimately helps organize and strengthen the financial relationship between the company and its clients.

The feature introduces an "Item PO Number" field (an external reference field) at the service contract item level, whereas it previously only existed at the header level. To make this PO number appear on the final invoice, a one-time configuration is required. A user must go into the system configuration for "Copying Control for Billing Documents" and set the control for sales documents to billing documents to include the "reference number" and "customer reference." Once configured, any value entered in the "Item PO Number" field on a service contract will be automatically copied to the corresponding line item on the invoice, which can then be viewed in apps like "Manage Billing Documents."

To ensure the item-level Purchase Order number successfully transfers to the final billing document, a specific configuration step is mandatory. This is not an automatic process. Within the "Configure Your Solution" app, navigate to the "Sales" application area and the "Sales Billing" sub-application area. Here, you will find the "Copying Control for Billing Documents" setting. The crucial action is to access the rule for "Define copying control for Sales Document to Billing Document" and enable the data transfer by selecting the options related to "Reference Number" and "Customer Reference." Completing this configuration creates the necessary link, ensuring that the value entered in the service contract item's PO number field is correctly copied and displayed on the corresponding invoice.

Watch this demo to have a complete view of the feature.

 

Change capabilities for mass updates of service contracts

You can now mass update service contracts with more attributes ‚Äì sales office and sales groups, billing block and billing block reason, and completed status.

This enhancement provides significant business value by improving the efficiency of managing large volumes of service contracts. Instead of performing tedious, one-by-one updates, users can now execute changes in bulk, saving considerable time and reducing the risk of manual errors. The ability to update organizational data like the Sales Office and Sales Group, or to change the lifecycle status of multiple contracts to 'Completed' or apply a billing block, allows businesses to react quickly to organizational shifts and streamline their contract management processes, ensuring data consistency and operational agility.

This feature introduces new capabilities within the "Mass Processing of Service Contracts" application. Users can now select a group of contracts and make several new header-level changes. Specifically, it is possible to modify the "Sales Office" and "Sales Group" by either deleting the existing value or replacing it with a new one. Additionally, the update allows users to apply a billing block with a corresponding reason, or to set the status of the selected contracts to "Completed." Once the changes are confirmed, a background batch job is triggered, and its success or failure can be tracked and debugged in the "Monitor Mass Process Service Transactions" app.

Watch this demo to have a complete view of the feature.

entry.title: Error M7053 - Posting period in goods movement
entry.content:
If you find the error M7053 as shown in the image below:

You can try to follow the steps:

First of all, it‚Äôs important to mention that we tried to post goods in 08/2025, but my posting period ended in 06/2025. Therefore, we first need to check and close the period for 07/2025, and only then will we be able to verify the latest period ‚Äî 08/2025.

1. Go to the app "Close Periods":

2. Fill the company code, the period - with the month (e.g. 07/2025) following the last posting period (e.g 06/2025) - and fiscal year boxe. Then select "Check and close periods": 

If you fill the period with the current month, like 08/2025 in this example, you are going to see the log below: 

3. So, after you close the period for 07/2025, you can repeat the same steps for the current month. After that, you should be able to perform postings goods in the current period.

entry.title: Overview, IAM, Cutover Plan -Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Live Customers
entry.content:
This is only relevant for Partners and Live Customers who are required to transit Production system data with EUR adoption in Bulgaria. In the first session offered by ASC Cloud ERP Expertise Services,  3 main topics are covered, General Overview, Authorizations and Access Management, and Cutover Plan Template.

  • Recording on August 12, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Overview)
  • Presentation on August 12, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Overview)
  • Accelerator:
    • Cutover Template Download
    • Authorizations and Access Management Guide

1. Key Discussion Points‚Äå

1.1 Project Background & Transition Process‚Äå

Objective‚Äå: Facilitate Bulgaria‚Äôs transition from BGN to EUR for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers by January 2026.

Critical Steps‚Äå:

Pre-November 2025 (CBC Customers only)‚Äå:
  • Create a new company code with EUR and leverage SAP Incident  (unconfirmed Company code status until SAP assigns EUR currency).
  • Deploy changes post-ticket closure.
Post-November 2025(CBC Customers only)‚Äå‚Äå:
  • Best practice content (Cloud Release 2508.3) will automate EUR company code creation.

Solution Builder Customers‚Äå: Must wait until November for updates.

1.2 IAM Adjustments‚Äå

Authorization Updates‚Äå:

  • Copy existing business roles, replace old company code references with EUR values.
  • Use ‚ÄåMass Change Wizard‚Äå for bulk updates (company code, profit center, etc.).
  • Test roles in development/test systems before production deployment.

1.3 Finance & Data Migration (Cutover Plan)‚Äå

  • Master Data‚Äå: Extend GL accounts, house banks & bank accounts, tax conditions, profit centers, cost centers, fixed assets, bank determination to payment methods, liquidity item queries, business partners, to new company code.
  • Transactional Data‚Äå: Migrate open items (AP/AR, GL, fixed assets postings) via ‚ÄåMigration Cockpit‚Äå.
  • Key Checks‚Äå:
    • Block old company code post-closing activities.
    • Validate currency exchange rates and reference currency settings.
    • Check view ‚ÄúSet Validity of Organizational Unit‚Äù in Document and Compliance Reporting settings
    • Copy ‚ÄúCash Journal‚Äù settings from BGN to EUR
    • Set up interest rates and reference interest rates for EUR
    • Set up your Situation Handling and Teams & Responsibilities for new company code

1.4 FAQs Highlight‚Äå

  • Transport Dependencies‚Äå: CBC transports must follow creation sequence (Bulgaria-related TRs first).

2. Live Questions & Answers

Topic Area

Question

Answer

Group Reporting

"Group reporting is not covered in cutover activities. Will there be a dedicated session for this?"

Cutover Excel sheet will include group reporting updates, enhanced in download version

Company Code Activation

"Should we activate the new company code now or wait until November?"

For CBC customers:

  • Tickets mandatory until November (SAP assigns EUR).
  • Post-November: Once you receive the contents and updates in November, you can create the new company code with EUR as default on your own yourself.  but you CANNOT do any scope extension/ add scope for BG until conversion to 3SL happens. 

Company Code Configuration

"Is an SAP ticket required for activation, or can we self-configure?"

Depends on business criticality: Start now for January operations; wait if flexibility allows.

Transport Requests

"Will Bulgaria-related TRs create dependencies with other project TRs?"

Complete existing TRs before 2508 release upgrade. Handle Bulgaria TRs sequentially with strict access controls.

Controlling Area Currency

"Does the controlling area currency need updating for single-company-code systems?"

Group currency cannot be changed post-setup. Reprovisioning needed if LEV was original currency.

Audit Corrections

"How to handle audit corrections (e.g., depreciation) post-migration?"

Retain limited access to old company code for reporting until audits conclude (July 2026).

Professional Services

"Will there be a session for Professional Services LOB?"

No standalone session planned. Questions may be addressed in upcoming supply chain/finance sessions.

3. Call-to-Action

Register and Attend Upcoming Webinar presented by SAP Service experts' with practical suggestions
  • [Aug 20th] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Supply Chain & SD & Procurement)  
  • [Aug 27th] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Data Migration)
  • [Sept 3rd] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Finance)
Please view all content and raise questions with tag #Bulgaria
